title: Advanced Television Studio Production
requirements: Pre-requisite: COMM3733.
description: This course focuses on advanced TV studio production techniques. Students will develop their own ideas and approaches for their projects. By studying the workflow of virtual sets and the integration of outdoor streaming, they will explore various genres and possibilities in TV entertainment. Students are required to write, produce, and direct high-quality works that meet professional standards.

title: New Media Advertising
description: This course examines new media as evolving advertising media. The emphasis is on understanding the technologies and theories of new media advertising. The course has been developed to guide students through the process of conceiving, executing, and evaluating new media advertising and to achieve an understanding of the subject from practical and theoretical perspectives.

title: Cinematography
requirements: Prerequisite: COMM2922.
description: This course approaches cinematography from both technical and creative aspects. It explores aesthetics in film-making, with emphasis on camera work, lighting design and the roles of cinematographer. Students are expected to experiment with various components in both theory and practice through the course of study.
outcome: Expected Learning Goals and Outcomes:  1. Students can demonstrate professional skills required to operate small digital camera. 2. Acquire a solid theoretical and practical basis for cinematography. 3. Students can apply analytical theories, camera composition and lighting technique for a video shoot. 4. Solving problems that arise from practical shoots. 5. To analyze a script for principal photography. 6. To communicate well with all team members on a shoot.
syllabus: (For reference only, subject to change) 1. What is Cinematography? 2. Video Camera Basics 3. Cinematic language 4. Introduction to Lighting and Grip Equipment 5. Analysis of script 6. Five Cs of Cinematography 7. Scene Coverage 8. Camera, Lighting and Production Design 9. Cinematography and Post Production 10. Media power and the myth of the extraordinary world
required_readings: Brown, B. (2002) Cinematography: Theory and Practice: Image Making for Cinematographers, Directors, and Videographers. USA: Elsevier Science, Focal Press.  Branigan, E. (2006) Projecting a Camera: Language-Games in Film Theory. London: Routledge.

title: Fundamentals of Computer Animation
description: This course is an animation practicum which builds upon the most current and advanced technical skills in animation production for television and film. In this intensive workshop students will have the opportunity to work with high-end software which currently is used by professionals working with computer graphics in animation. The course covers the entire animation process including modeling, lighting, shading, animation and rendering. Student will be trained both to conceptualize and execute animation projects.

outcome: By the end of this course, students are expected to be able to demonstrate advanced photographic skills such as specific photography techniques for products, protraits and scenery.

title: Statistical Analysis in Communication
requirements: For students in MPhil Communication or PhD Communication or MA Global Communication
description: This course aims at introducing graduate students to the study of the scientific discipline of communication. The course covers analyses of data using the general linear model. Topics include simple and multiple regression, analysis of variance and covariance, tests of significance, the interpretation of model parameters and other topics like path analysis and structural equation modeling as time allows. Students are expected to conduct a complete quantitative research and analysis at the end of the course.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should gain a clear understanding of the concepts and techniques of statistical analysis. Students should be able to: • Use SPSS to perform statistical analysis; • Choose appropriate statistical techniques to perform hypothesis tests; • Perform and interpret various statistical tests including Z test, t-tests, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, correlation and regression analyses; and  • Report the results of a statistical analysis.

title: Quantitative Communication Research
requirements: For students in MPhil Communication or PhD Communication
description: This course provides an introduction to social scientific methods in communication research. It has two foci: 1) the epistemological and methodological principles of social science approach to communication; and 2) the skills in data handling. Issues covered including concept formation, hypothesis development, research design, sampling, and data gathering and analysis.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should gain a clear understanding of the following: • The logic of social scientific research in communication; • Methods of framing research questions and techniques of gathering and interpreting empirical observations in an effort to answer a wide range of research questions; and • The boundaries of the scientific approach to knowledge, the limits of quantitative methods in general, their techniques, assumptions, the strengths and weaknesses of particular methods and critiques of specific design. Students should become more critical and discerning in their consumption of research findings; and are able to make appropriate problem/method(s) linkage in real-world settings.

description: This course applies interpersonal and social theories in and for the context of public relations. By applying the work of a group of prominent interpersonal and social theorists, this course will explore together with students a different perspective to understand the public relations practices, processes and consequences/impact in the contemporary societies at the macro and micro levels. With the emerging importance of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, focus will be given to business sectors in this Area. Case studies will be used to illustrate Public Relations practitioners' front-line experiences in the region.

title: Communication in Intercultural Settings
